title: US finalizes proposed direct-to-smartphone regulatory framework
summary: U.S. regulators will vote March 14 on a regulatory framework for allowing satellites to use radio waves from terrestrial mobile operators to keep their smartphone users connected beyond the reach of cell towers.

title: Blue Origin has emerged as the likely buyer for United Launch Alliance
summary: Pairing of two launch companies could provide more robust competition to SpaceX.

title: IM-1 lander enters lunar orbit
summary: Intuitive Machines’ first lunar lander mission entered orbit around the moon Feb. 21, setting up a landing attempt in a day.

title: Former U.S. Space Force chief Jay Raymond joins board of directors of Impulse Space
summary: Raymond retired from military service in October 2022.

title: Hughes’ networking software selected for Air Force satellite internet experiment
summary: A demonstration run by SES Space & Defense will integrate satellites in geostationary, medium and low orbits

title: SpaceX Senior Vice President Tom Ochinero is leaving the company in a rare high-level departure
summary: One of SpaceX’s senior executives is leaving, CNBC has learned, in a rare high-level departure from Elon Musk’s space company.

title: NASA faces a quandary with its audacious lunar cargo program
summary: Failure is now an option at the US space agency.

title: TEXUS-59 Science Mission Successfully Launched from Esrange
summary:
The joint DLR/ESA TEXUS-59 suborbital science mission was successfully launched on 15 February from Esrange Space Center in Sweden. TEXUS-59 was launched at 14:42 UTC aboard a two-stage Brazilian VSB-30 sounding rocket. The rocket reached a maximum apogee of 264.5 kilometres before returning back to Earth. It was then recovered, allowing researchers to examine the […]
The post TEXUS-59 Science Mission Successfully Launched from Esrange appeared first on European Spaceflight.

title: Impending European satellite reentry highlights debris mitigation challenges
summary: The impending reentry of a defunct European satellite serves as a reminder of the hazards posed by existing objects even as agencies work to mitigate the growth of orbital debris.
